awd_titl_txt: Information Disclosure and Financial Markets: An Experimental Investigation
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

The disclosure of information regarding the financial condition of firms has been a centerpiece of financial market regulation since the passage of the Securities Exchange Act in 1934. Requirements have been refined and reinforced over time with regulations which was intended to improve the accuracy and reliability of corporate disclosures, and more recently mandates that banks and other financial institutions periodically report results of stress tests that assess the institution’s capacity to respond to highly adverse events. An important issue regards the amount of the information collected that regulatory authorities should disclose publicly. Although the disclosure of firm-specific information typically improves the price efficiency of markets, there are concerns about this on several fronts: Public disclosure may undermine risk sharing opportunities between banks, may drive firms to invest in short term projects that yield high immediate returns in lieu of more profitable longer term projects, and may interfere with the capacity of markets to effectively aggregate information. This project uses laboratory experiments to investigate the behavioral relevance of recent theoretical models that analyze these important issues on information disclosure in the financial markets.

The project consists of three experiments. The first experiment evaluates a model which provides a framework for balancing the concern that excessive information disclosure of a bank’s condition may undermine the risk-sharing opportunities that interbank markets allow, against the general perception that disclosure improves price efficiency. The second experiment evaluates the predictions of a model that focuses on the issue that overly frequent disclosures may force institutions to forego more profitable long term projects in favor of alternative projects that yield higher short term returns. The third experiment evaluates the effects of different kinds of public disclosure on a market’s capacity to aggregate information. Overall, these experiments advances the body of knowledge on information disclosure in the financial markets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The collection and dissemination of information regarding the financial condition of firms has long been a centerpiece of financial market regulation.  Both the specificity and frequency of required financial disclosures by firms and banks have increased in recent years with federal legislation such as the Sarbanes Oxley Act (2002) and the Dodd Frank Act (2010). The extent to which this newly collected information that should be disclosed publicly has become a subject of considerable debate.  Although the disclosure of firm-specific information typically improves the price efficiency of markets by allowing traders to impound more information into the institution’s asset price, disclosures may in some instances weaken a market’s economic efficiency.  The research funded under this grant used laboratory methods to investigate the behavioral relevance of theoretical models of financial disclosures on market efficiency. The difficulty of directly observing the underlying condition of a financial institution in natural contexts, as well as to the virtual impossibility of identifying what either managers or investors know about this condition make laboratory methods ideally suited to this sort of empirical inquiry. 

We focused on the predictions of three policy-relevant models of information disclosures.  A first project studied the effects of variations in information pooling on risk sharing activities.   Here the pertinent policy issue regards the reporting of the bank stress test results mandated under the Dodd Frank Act (2010).  Policy makers have debated at length whether the stress test results should be bank specific or pooled into groups.  We evaluate a theoretical model by Goldstein and Leitner (2018) that suggests that in constructing a disclosure policy, the regulator needs to balance an interest in identifying insolvent banks for investors against a concern for maintaining the solvency of liquidity stressed but solvent banks, which can be maintained with an appropriate pooling.  Despite a propensity for laboratory creditors to overbid for the assets of a firm, our experimental results generally support the predictions in environments where solvency concerns are likely to be an issue, 

A second project evaluates the effects of changes in the required frequency of financial reports managerial investment decisions, as analyzed by Gigler et al. (2014). Here the concern regards the tradeoff between incentives toward over-investment, which arise when managers report infrequently and can only signal financial growth by choosing to invest, and ‘short termism’, which can be induced by a desire for immediate investment returns when reports must be submitted at short intervals.   As part of this project we also investigated the impact of increased communications between managers and investors, a policy often recommended by y analysts as a way to increase investment efficiency. Experimental results here indicate that while frequent reporting does induce short-termism, as predicted by Gigler et al. (2014), frequent reporting fails to reduce overinvestment. On the other hand, allowing managers to send nonbinding messages of intended investments plan does reduce overinvestment, but only with infrequent reporting, because infrequent reporting simplifies the set actions to which managers can credibly commit.

Our third project experiment assess the behavioral relevance of predictions of a model by Goldstein and Yang (2019) regarding public information disclosures in a multi-component environment. The policy issue in this third investigation regards the disclosures a real decision maker (e.g., an investor in a cash constrained firm) might make in order to learn from the market about a dimension of a multi-component asset  A potential investor, for example, may have access to corporate records and thus be considerably better informed than the market about the financial condition of a firm. On the other hand, the investor may have no better information than any other trader about other aspects of the firm, such as viability of expansion plans into new or distant markets. Goldstein and Yang suggest that to better learn about this latter component the real decision maker should publicly disclose what she knows about the component for which she is better informed, since doing so will allow traders to focus their trading intensity on the other component and thus improve information aggregation. Our experimental outcomes are in the direction predicted by Goldstein and Yang (2019). Nevertheless, the magnitude of the responses to the public announcements are smaller than predicted and are driven not by an improved capacity for traders to aggregate information, as the model suggests, but rather by traders simply having better information overall following the release of an accurate signal.  Thus, our results suggest that a prior information model (e.g., where traders make value decisions in light of their own information and the public messages of the market) organizes outcomes much more effectively than does a strong form rational expectations model.
